document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

C0F310ED1A6C4EAFA8EF07CF7DDFA0D2.description:
Complex and advanced learning standards in Ohio’s New
Learning Standards are not included in the extended
standards.

33296C9595BE4143A71C996F0A628AD7.description:
Stoichiometry
• Molar calculations
• Solutions
• Limiting reagents

D75707B2556C4319A53C6FA136924AB9.description:
Identify common gases (air, water vapor, oxygen, helium,
carbon dioxide).

8AB5AF88672A4E3183B564138D8A7EF8.description: Identify that empty containers are filled with gas (air).

9112EAD6DDFC457F8A5446DB917E75BA.description:
Use a balloon to demonstrate how temperature affects the
volume of a gas (freezing a balloon with air will cause the
molecules to move slowly and deflate the balloon; bringing
balloon to room temperature will increase the size of the
ballon because the molecules are moving faster hitting the
edges of the balloon, increasing size).

D446D03E69E849699D1BE98D734BF432.description:
Recognize that temperature, volume and pressure impact
behavior of gases.

901D6CC2825843D894316BDB6ABE09F5.description:
Recognize that when the volume of a gas is decreased the
pressure will increase (popping a balloon by squeezing it).

BCD68335F8BF4584BA87698C32083AF6.description:
Recognize that when the temperature of a gas is
increased its volume will increase (tire pressure on a hot
day, hot air balloon rises).

040443101E2640E2AA244C25A80523E1.description:
Define gas
as having no definite
shape or volume.

9CAC466993264287B6AEAE38B9C903B0.description:
Identify
types of
measurements
used for measuring
gases (volume,
temperature, and
pressure).

FA662784F2954B078CEA80433D9C5DB3.description:
Gas laws
• Pressure, volume, and
temperature
• Ideal gas law

0BB8D199B6A24355819B7DA577E5593F.description:
Relate everyday experiences to the pH scale (how acidic
foods like lemons taste, how bases like soap feel slippery).

BB09FC3556D8434E92C1B32BD70E4C79.description:
Recognize that acidity is measured on a scale (pH) that
goes from very acidic (1) to very basic (14) and that the
center point (7) is considered neutral.

B4D80F1CCF58422099769BF3F16B34F8.description:
Categorize everyday objects (or pictures) into groups of
acides, bases, and neutral.

14F4C98140B64755B03020E55FD3B6BB.description:
Represent the pH scale with pictures of products that
range from 1-14 (e.g., orange juice to water to soap).

916E862051B14B73A54F576C6AB33F4B.description:
Test various acids and bases with universal indicator
(liquid or strips are easily purchased from science
suppliers) to find the pH of the substance.

40BEE1C05E5E4DAE87EA5A936E2278DB.description:
Watch a chemical reaction (in class or virtually), identify
that bonds are being broken and formed using models.

78BB96458574434EAABD80C58D6A8236.description:
Recognize that there are a variety of ways that chemical
reactions can happen, two of which are combustion and
neutralization.

C0DE082291664C9DBB9F635416A265E4.description:
Observe mixing an acid with a base to recognize a
neutralization reaction (many cosmetology processes such
as perms or dyes involve neutralization).

B94F63D3B4B84BBDBA680D1CB1E7F83A.description:
Observe combustion (burning a candle, starting a grill,
having a campfire, household furnace) in class or virtually
to recognize a combustion reaction.

FB64DA476B184013B09A41BD4D044080.description:
Visually show that combustion is fuel + oxygen + a small
energy source to form water, carbon dioxide, and ash
while releasing larger amounts of energy in the form of
heat and light.

613F7B572F15425F839272AFD81E6E2F.description:
Identify
acid, neutral, and/
or base on a pH
scale.

08BC5A9EE2F14686B13C6A6A47553402.description:
Given a pH
scale with common
ingredients (e.g.,
orange juice, water,
baking soda),
determine if they are
acid, neutral, or basic.

BA7DFF47AAB44502B3769A924DE5FF94.description:
Use litmus
paper to test and
determine the pH
of a substance.

10F2112930BA47FFA98D5DB5A21B7000.description:
Chemical reactions
• Types of reactions
• Kinetics
• Energy
• Equilibrium
• Acids/bases

DB733421E5E646609864B191C9BB6729.description:
Recognize that a mixture is two more more substances
combined but not chemically joined.

B36DAFEA183840768D93A5F79A7A1C70.description:
Recognize solutions as mixtures that are evenly
distributed throughout and show components visually
(sugar, water, sugar, water, sugar, water).

64E6743CB7F24C21AD37B4147E16B9BA.description:
Recognize that dissolve means to distribute the particles
of one substance throughout another substance.

E241A64621D34BFCB1CF0A80815D1904.description:
Observe a set of mixtures (can be pictures or virtual) and
choose the ones that are solutions (salt water, rubbing
alcohol from the drug store).

DE6D9239BCB44F3AA4C62304ED5073FE.description:
Understand that fresh water differs from salt water and
that humans cannot drink salt water for hydration (some
sea creatures can use salt water).

8BAD3BA7DF6841539832F7814D4CECE0.description:
Make a solution by combining two substances (sugar and
water, salt water, powdered drink mix).

A997E3C520A14BB5ACB882E95783DA59.description:
Recognize that saturated means the maximum amount
of a substance possible is dissolved (e.g., salt or sugar
begins to visibly collect in the water; (Use a set amount of
water, find the maximum amount of salt that can dissolve
(saturated solution), change the temperature and see if
more or less can be dissolved (hotter water will dissolve
more salt).

C7C67DD9ED26439792E345BD73753E35.description:
Identify
a solution when
given a field of
choices.

A52211250A7341538A31D3E5A6259B7B.description:
Perform
a task with a fixed
amount of water
and given amounts
of a solute (e.g.,
powdered drink mix)
to observe solutions
and supersaturated
solutions.

020F423540BF4D51A2130D21797B37E8.description:
Explore
the properties of
water and how
they change when
water is part of a
solution (e.g., salt
water solutions).

B9AB57108388453DBDA968F8A93EDBA8.description:
Intermolecular
chemical bonding forces of
attraction
• Types and strengths
• Implications for properties of
substances
• Melting and boiling point
• Solubility
• Vapor pressure

C9929F15325143EC86837B12EC00983C.description:
Complex and advanced learning standards in Ohio’s New
Learning Standards are not included in the extended
standards.

EC28DCBDFDD34F89BC1460D3EC33CFAB.description:
Use a model to investigate that two or more elements can
join to form a compound.

229867BC2CB04DBFB5FD65D1C6DC3521.description:
Match common elements and their symbols to develop
compounds and formulas (hydrogen, oxygen, carbon ,
nitrogen).

6E582E9AA06A449EB5B1ACC1887F9938.description:
Use a ball and stick model to represent a chemical
formula.

6CE9EB696C364CBEA3A74BC27B2F96EB.description:
Look at ball and stick or other models to identify the parts
(atoms of elements) that make up a compound.

DB350F2913184B2EBA578496A7DE4361.description:
Use symbols for elements and subscripts to represent a
compound observed in a ball and stick model (observe a
model of water to discover the formula H2O).

D2681248AE4E450A99D6C2BEAE50E58E.description:
Identify a
compound as two
or more elements
coming together
(combining).

D580E0134CF7424EBC0D13E009263F5B.description:
Build a
model of a chemical
compound in a variety
of ways (e.g., balland-stick model).

23362D01AD1D424EAF204379B6371177.description:
Represent
a chemical
compound with
a ball-and-stick
model or chemical
formula.

11480CB3480D476C9EE443098B58E08B.description:
Representing
compounds
• Formula writing
• Nomenclature
• Models and shapes (Lewis
structures, ball-and-stick,
molecular geometries)

EC3ABF8AE2C54D77A7F29CBAAA4A3B4D.description:
Recognize that different atoms react in different ways
(ionic and covalent bonding).

29AEB7DF4CA040AC918219A055F64CA5.description:
Recognize that in covalent bonding atoms share valence
electrons so that each have 8.

845393056CB84BB0A512C300F0BF8067.description:
Recognize that ionic bonding is an attraction between
oppositely charged ions.

DC4D29474DBB4E98BB268C3D705CB8D4.description:
Recognize an ion as an atom that has gained or lost
valence electrons (which changes their electrical charge).

260EAE2A2AC34BE78743286E4093894F.description:
Identify common substances that are bonded ionically and
covalently.

FB7407056E8A429695255FE1C4D0882F.description:
Use an atomic model and/or video to investigate that
atoms interact to achieve 8 valence electrons (view the
product).

68112AAAACE14C1AB3A4F1D4CA2EA51F.description:
Combine (baking soda and vinegar, glue and laundry
starch) or observe a simple compound (salt, water, sugar)
identify that it is composed of more than one type of atom
bonded together.

4764A844D3A54A4BB4DF00CB5127EDD1.description:
Identify
bonding as
an interaction
between atoms.

07BBC632E0A7485D925A9AE73462E2D1.description:
Compare
the characteristics of
an ionic bond and a
covalent bond.

92EB874E99A04630A1BE3FEA674378B7.description:
Identify
the type of
chemical bonding
that has occurred
in a given
compound.

20FDB073F8F94FEA8656230AF056C0CF.description: Use a Periodic Table’s key to recognize elements.

781D74E8BD6A4A4A90E5B83484421569.description:
Recognize the location of the atomic number of an
element on the Periodic Table.

79103C2D010E49EFB545669DEC2DFA4C.description:
Identify atoms based on their atomic number (given a
number find the name of an element).

BEC1668EFE4B47BEAE77075129596F03.description:
Recognize that elements in the same column have similar
properties.

1E666F2A145346AFBF3B030CEF134458.description:
Given an element, find another element on the Periodic
Table that will have similar properties (choose one in the
same column).

B730D026DCA04B8D817E0B7B35A886B3.description:
Know that elements in the same column have the same
number of valence electrons.

0E52C13E7019447A8F9798FE4810FDBF.description:
Identify various categories of elements on the Periodic
Table (e.g., groups, families, periods, metals, nonmetals
and metalloids).

BCF121889AC04028BDA2709E19328980.description:
Follow the progression of atomic numbers on the Periodic
Table and note their reactivity.

588A61BB381743A0ACF24F572EEDC888.description:
Identify
an element(s) on
the periodic table.

8E3F9F0DF8F44299A93BF2487838C89F.description:
Recognize
that elements are
organized on the
periodic table by their
properties, number of
protons, and number
of outer electrons.

B3A1D56F1A0B438CADDEFB6E4109B38A.description:
Use the
periodic table to
answer questions
about types of
elements and
the properties
of elements
(e.g., number of
outer electrons,
groupings).

02C54BBB715B4812B0A75AF88D5135C8.description: Engage with a model of an atom.

A15B2BFCF2D54A8A8389F9161BEE1C87.description:
Select the diagram that shows an atom from a set of
drawings.

1BCB5B7EC1FA47C9BED285088AFE4A9E.description:
Place labels (protons, neutrons, electrons) on a drawing of
an atom.

BF0A38D5B69D4153BE5CFA1028A24479.description:
Identify that protons have a positive charge, neutrons are
neutral, and electrons have a negative charge.

355B8B8B51454C32B5E9CA781C819308.description:
Recognize that valence electrons are in the outside layer
of an atom.

BE93B099FE9B45B08A555090229414FC.description:
Recognize that an atom’s reactivity is based on its valence
electrons.

2B5DD7EC8C5E4DFB814804E5AC804E23.description:
Identify the valence electrons on a drawing or model on an
atom.

AB2C451EDBD54F99839220BF8DC1F7F6.description:
Build a model of an atom including protons, neutrons or
electrons.

A9774D07C45846548BBD0A9708F77FD9.description:
Identify a
diagram or model
of an atom.

A188B7A6388B4707B2AF67EB3E46A51B.description:
Identify
part(s) of an atom
(i.e., protons,
neutrons, electrons).

8C061C001C404947A8E301EC014573F7.description:
Identify
the location of a
valence electron
and/or how
valance electrons
affect an atom’s
interactions.

22355EB0ECD04C4B883384EC5DDF5721.description:
Atomic structure
• Evolution of atomic models/
theory
• Electrons
• Electron configurations
